Also, CGI ≠ no colour grading, Blade Runner 2049 is an example of someone (Roger Deakins) going the extra mile to match the colour palette of whats shot with the CGI. It’s entirely possible and can be incredible, but it’s work that some people clearly don’t want to do https://t.co/JuSekcuKXt

I will say however that I truly wish colour grading wasn’t so flat and boring in modern movies atm, but when Marvel - who makes nearly a billion with most movies - get away with it, why would others bother? It’s an extra cost that some studios clearly can’t be bothered to pay

So, one thing. Marvel movies pride themselves on secrecy, which takes a lot of green screen work. Especially as huge sequences start to be completely CGI, it’s much harder to have any real creative control over colour balance, so instead grading becomes flat to accommodate CGI https://t.co/lhuGwcrcOr

I think my only gripe is that this does retread some of the Nolan stuff, and while he loved a huge wide frame and bombastic action, Reeves shoots so closely and with really shallow focal lengths, so the action can very occasionally get lost in the mix and feel underwhelming.

Also, Robert deserves a pat on the bat. This Bruce Wayne is anguished, he’s ferocious, and he’s unstoppable. I can’t wait to see more of this version, especially how he grows after the events of this film. Him and Serkis were amazing together.

The Batmobile feels like a monster, all the actors bring everything to their parts, and the MUSIC and sound design! I already can’t wait to watch this again. I think it could have been 20 minutes shorter as some sections drag, but you can a whole lot of great Batman here

The Batman was absolutely phenomenal, an intimate and intricate detective story with this Batman at the heart of all of it. The day he died, my grandad called me at 7am to tell me, and as soon as I finished work I drove to his house, and we stayed up all night listening to our favourite albums, reminiscing, raising a drink to the man himself. Truly, a genius, an original, and he’ll be loved forever.

Bowie was a constant in my life, so when he came back with Where Are We Now and Blackstar, both fantastic albums, it was gift to my later adult years. I later realised they were bookends to his career and life, and still struggle to listen to Blackstar.

Then, the year afterwards my grandad took us to two gigs in two days, both in Birmingham NEC. While last year was small, here Bowie was performing to an arena & thousands of people, commanding every eye in the room. His voice filled the space somehow, effortlessly powerful.

I was 12 years old the first time I saw Bowie, at a launch event for the album Heathen in London. They started by playing Low in its entirety, a weird album I was then obsessed with for life. Later the Dandy Warhols came on for the encore, doing White Light White Heat with Bowie.

Happy 75th birthday to Ziggy Stardust, Aladdin Sane, The Thin White Duke, The Man Who Fell To Earth, The Goblin King himself… David Bowie. My childhood hero in music, expression, and sheer imagination. Grateful to say I caught you live more than once, and I’ll never forget it. https://t.co/ezFWfJOHn5

Don’t really have a point with this other than to try and be visibly honest about mental health. We all have it, so there more we chat the easier it is. I’m happy to have a chat with any mutuals if they need to vent, and offer support/compliments/dog pictures where I can.

I’m also grateful I’ve got great friends, a fantastic partner & two beautiful dogs who fill me with joy every day. But it takes work, it takes constant attention, mental health is something that never goes away. Take help where you can, rest where you can, and love yourself.

I am grateful that at those lows I had people around me, I have found good therapists (eventually) and occasionally the NHS has actually been there to help as well. It’s fucking tough out there, and using any resource available is better than the alternative.

Yesterday was #WorldMentalHealthDay and I didn’t really fancy talking about it then, but today has been better. Anxiety and depression have changed my life, but I don’t let them define it. I’ve had some awful, awful lows and needed real help, and luckily I’ve made it out alive/ https://t.co/H5OKCgLMOz
